title.narrative: Women on the Frontline MENA

description.narrative: In 2011, people all over the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region went to the streets to demand their rights. During that time, the hopes and expectations for a just, democratic and prosperous region were high, and women played a central role in these events. New initiatives addressing the role of women in society and politics flourished, women’s rights were debated, and women’s groups showed a willingness to put aside their differences in order to work together on common goals. It was in this context that the Women on the Frontline (WoF) programme was developed. This programme was set up to strengthen women’s groups across the region to contribute to the meaningful participation of women, and has set up partnerships with thirty women’s organisations from Iraq, Syria, Yemen, Bahrain, Egypt, Libya and Tunisia. The aim of the programme is to promote women's active participation in political processes on several levels by providing diverse kinds of support to existing and emerging women’s rights organisations. The WoF programme enables women to take their message to a wider audience, including decision-makers, both at home and abroad. This empowers women to make a vital contribution towards achieving peace, security and equality in the MENA region. WoF liaises to help local activists campaign for change at the local and national level and increase their impact by reaching out to powerful international actors. The implementers ultimate long-term vision for the next twenty years is that by 2025, women in the MENA region will be politically and socially empowered. A level playing field for women will have been created, providing space for a gender-sensitive discourse based on the concept of citizenship, and reversing the current trend of shrinking space for civil society. The new discourse will offer an alternative to increased conservatism, repression, and extremism. A broad collective of female leaders and activists will hold state and non-state actors to account, and will be agents of change in building a peaceful, equal, and just society. In order to achieve this aim, the next generation of activists workings towards gender equality must be strengthened, visual, and recognised as relevant actors by their constituency and by decision makers. Long-term goals of WoF: 1. Women leaders will have become decision-makers 2. More women will have become influential actors at the national political level and in peace building and conflict resolution. 3. There will be increased recognition of women and activists working towards gender equality as relevant actors for change. Women leaders effectively work towards transformative change and for women’s rights. Citizenship is a leading principle in public debates.

title.narrative: Increased recognition by (inter)national decision makers of the need for women’s political participation and gender equality
An article about WoF's work in academic journal Gender and Development has been published

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative: article has been published in an academic journal

In the Extension Phase, journalist Dido Michielsen wrote an article about the WoF programme: ‘Women on the Frontline: can a network provide a platform for activists in the volatile MENA region?’.The article is published in the online journal ‘Gender & Development

title.narrative: Increased visibility and influence of women and activists working towards gender equality as actors of change in society
WOF website is maintained - including image archive development and continuous production of stories and news items

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative: website was well maintained and bettered and a new special film website was added too

title.narrative: WoF facebook page has developed into active exchange forum, including substantial increase of followers

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

title.narrative: Number of visual narratives that have been produced

comment.narrative: Under the VOICE pillar, we implemented activities to advocate for women’s rights and promote a discourse of peace and inclusivity. Through the tailor-made trainings conducted under the LEARN pillar, we empowered WoF members to develop strategic visibility strategies and targeted communication, especially via social media. Hereby, we made women’s voices and stories heard and we created more space for an alternative discourse on WPS, WPP and VAW in the MENA region. Through our advocacy work, we also enabled women to successfully influence and stress the urgency of placing WPS, WPP and VAW high on national and international political agendas and be regarded as actors of change in society. brief overview: 1) 5 regional films 2) one yezidi film 3) six articles on VAW in 16 days campaign FB campaign which resulted in hunderds of Visuals and articles

title.narrative: Media outreach: At least three articles have been published in Dutch and international media outlets

comment.narrative: the Extension Phase, the WoF programme was mentioned multiple times in national and international media outlets. The publication of articles and our appearance in news and radio shows contributed to an increased awareness on the importance of women working towards gender equality as actors of change in the MENA region. In addition, it led to an increased visibility of our programme. in total 5 times on radio, tv and in newspapers and so on

title.narrative: Number of frontrunners video stories that have been produced
An increased number of strong, sustainable and resilient CSOs and civil actors working towards women's rights and gender equality
The integrated Capacity Assessment Tool (CAT) will have been developed, filled out by all partners and analysed. Individual action plans will have been made based on the CAT with all partners

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised as a percentage

comment.narrative: All Women on the Frontline partners were invited to fill in the CAT. The CAT consisted of a needsassessment, where the partners could indicate where they would like support on, a self-assessment,where the partners could indicate how they perceived their own capacities per element, and an actual assessment with for each element of the CAT closed and open questions. PwC verified the results through an assessment of additional documentation provided by our partners, such as annual reports.

title.narrative: Inception meeting for all WoF members is held - including set up of action plans for each WoF partner based on the outcome of the Capacity

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative: In the Extension Phase, we organised an inception meeting for the Women on the Frontline members. The inception meeting resulted in initial outline for individual action plans for the year 2017 for each CSO. The action plans indicate the organisation’s goals, strategies, planned interventions and training needs. The session also enabled us to define priority themes, overall outcomes, and cooperation opportunities at national and regional level for the next phase of Women on the Frontline.

title.narrative: Number of visibility trainings that have taken place

comment.narrative: Because of the shortened implementation period we organized two visibility trainings for WoF-Members. In the Extension Phase, we organised two visibility trainings for WoF members EMMA (Iraqi Kurdistan) and one in Syria. The training sessions aimed at skills improvement and were tailor-made to ensure that the capacity developmental needs of the supported CSOs were met. Both training sessions had a specific focus on strengthening the alternative discourse on peace, justice and gender equality in the region, aimed at countering ideologies of violence and dominant discourses of extremism and polarisation. In order to ensure that the visibility training sessions under the LEARN pillar were concretely interlinked with and connected to activities under the other strategic Women on the Frontline 27 March 2017 we designed the training content as such, that the outputs would feed into the VOICE pillar. As a result, the visibility training sessions (LEARN), enabled the training participants to develop advocacy and campaign plans (VOICE) aimed at promoting moderate and inclusive visions in the region.

title.narrative: Number of change trainings that have taken place

comment.narrative: In order to ensure true ownership of the Stories of Change Research, Oxfam organised individual instruction meetings to make sure all WoF members understood the approach, had a relevant research question to work with and were well informed on how information should be collected and how their stories would be used. In addition, Oxfam Novib provided a Stories of Change training session in Istanbul between 14 and 15 December 2016.

title.narrative: Number of group trainings on Monitoring and Evaluation

comment.narrative: one training on MEAL and one on stories ofchange

title.narrative: More women effectively influence a gender sensitive Peace and Security agenda
Number of advocacy activities on Women, Peace and Security that have been carried out

comment.narrative:
1)trip to Europe, canada and US
2) Iraqi-Dutch exchange including a formal invite to parliament by the foreign affairs committee and see before
3) advocacy in the Netherlands Apart from regular and ongoing contacts with Dutch Members of Parliament, updating them on the role of women in the MENA region and especially on the Syrian peace talks, Hivos formulated a letter regarding the budgetary resources of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation made available for 2017. The letter calls upon the Minister to be aware of the high importance of investing sufficient resources in climate change, food security and sustainability, terrorism, migration and human rights. The letter also addressed the specific role that women, girls and youth play in achieving social change and called upon the Ministry to take this delicate role into account
4) advocacy in the MENA region In the MENA region, Hivos provided support for a strategic advocacy-planning meeting for twenty-six women’s rights leaders from eleven MENA countries, organised by Karama. The meeting took place in Cairo, Egypt between 29-30 December 2016. During the meeting, a one-year strategic plan to advance the Women, Peace, and Security agenda, addressing both regional and national concerns, was developed. The meeting was organised at a strategic moment in time: the United States was only weeks from inaugurating a new president, Donald Trump, who had expressed intense hostility toward the region. Therefore, we considered it essential to support Arab women leaders to unite and prepare for 2017, and underline the urgency of placing WPS, WPP and VAW high on national and international political agendas
and of course at the national level several advocacy activities havetaken place too

title.narrative: At least two projects in Syria and one project in Iraq have been supported

comment.narrative: In the Extension Phase, Hivos supported four partner organisations in Syria, one partner in Iraq and one WoF member in Libya

title.narrative: Number of projects in Egypt, Yemen and Tunisia that have been supported

comment.narrative:
In the Extension Phase, Oxfam Tunisia organised a national strategic session in October 2016. AllTunisian Wof partners participated in the session. The meeting offered the space for partners to evaluate Women on the Frontline Phase one, to update the context analysis for Tunisia and to identify the priorities for Tunisia on the selected theme of Women Political Participation for the next two years. As an outcome of the workshop, a two-year logical framework was co-developed with the partners, ensuring synergy and coherent planning at national level.
Due to the situation in Egypt we can not provdie any details
Due to the long authorisation processes by government body MOPIC (Yemen), it was not possible to transfer large amounts of project funding to our Yemeni partners. Instead, Oxfam organised activities in the field of strategic planning and project management.

title.narrative: Two expert Meetings on Countering/preventing Violent Extremism in the Hague and in the United States have been organised

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative: we had several meetings on CVE and PVE but for security reasons we can not inform you more

title.narrative: Voices of Women on the frontline voices are amplified and strengthen an alternative discourse on peace, justice, gender equality and Violence Against Women
Facebook campaign - countering violent extremism has been carried out

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative: In order to promote the FB campaign, a Syrian organisation printed and distributed 15.000 leaflets and banners inside Syria, and launched a Facebook Page and Twitter Page. In addition, they organised eight advocacy round tables inside Syria in order to ensure the active participation of women in the campaign. More than 300 women attended the round tables The campaign team adjusted the content and set up of those meetings in accordance with the local security circumstances. They also published over 100 articles on its website and Facebook page about the role of women in conflict situations and peace processes. By the end of 2016, their Facebook Page received more than 41.000 page likes and reached over 640.000 people.

title.narrative: An advocacy tour highlighting the work of WoF via five short films, in four cities in Europe, North America has taken place.

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative:
The advocacy tour included advocacy meetings and film screenings. We arranged screenings in five cities worldwide: The Hague, Washington DC, New York City, Ottawa and Tunis. Three Women on the Frontline activists travelled along and participated in panel discussions during the screenings: Bahar Ali (EMMA, Iraqi Kurdistan), Bilqis Abu Osba (AWAM, Yemen) and Yasmin Merei (Saiedat Souria, Syria). The goal of those panel discussions was to facilitate a dialogue on peace processes, UNSCR 1325, Preventing and Countering Violent Extremism (PVE/CVE) and community resilience between international influential actors and activists working on the ground in the MENA region.
We met in the US several high ranking officuals from statedepartment, USAID and from UN agnencies while attending the annnual session on UNSCR!325 and higlighting the case of MENA region women's activisms. In Canada, we emt amongst others ,Mr Peter M. Boehm, Deputy Minister of international Development. In the Netherlands we met among others with a number of ambassadors of the Dutch MFA.

title.narrative: Number of stories of WoF members during the "16 days campaign" against gender based violence that have been highlighted

comment.narrative: On 25 November 2016, UN Women launched an international campaign called “16 Days of Activism Against Gender-Based Violence Campaign”. In the context of this campaign, Hivos published the “Women on the Frontline 16 days campaign”: a series of stories on the work done by WoF members in the field of ending violence against women in Syria. Over the last years, the Assad government has arrested, tortured, and killed women at unprecedented rates while rebel and extremist groups of all ideologies have engaged in the systematic marginalisation and repression of Syrian women within their respective territories.

title.narrative: Increased collective impact through enhanced cooperation between CSOs and relevant stakeholders
Regional meeting including a public day for relevant stakeholders

description.narrative: extent to which all planned elements have been realised, as a percentage

comment.narrative:
In November 2016, we organised a Regional Meeting in Tunis, Tunisia, with the overall aim to enhance cooperation between the consortium and the participating WoF CSOs. The specific objectives of the Regional Meeting were: 1) to give the WoF members an update on the Women on the Frontline programme while enhancning the partnership/ network/ faciliting a space for dialogue and exchange ; 2) to create individual action plans; and 3) to interest relevant stakeholders and donors for Women on the Frontline Phase II. The meeting brought together 22 organisations, originating from six Women on the Frontline countries. Due to visa procedures issues not all could come. However, they participated via Skype.
During the public event, we screened five films portraying the work of individual Women on the Frontline activists. The film screening was opened by theambassador of the Kingdom of the Netherlands Mr Hans van Vleuten Dissevelt.
